7. 
The feature of the "discovery" instrument which we 
omitted to comprehend is peculiar to that instrument. 
Mr Bernacchi had had experience with the 
normal type and was one of the observers. 
It is not accurate therefore to assume that 
the difficulty would not have arisen had the members of 
the Expedition possessed more experience of another 
instrument in which no such difficulty could arise; 
but it may safely be said that there would have been no 
difficulty at all had an explanation of our instrument 
been enclosed in the box which contained it and which was received by the Expedition at so late a date. 
Dr Shaw's statement that questions arise as 
to temperature differences indicated by adjacent 
thermometers is extremely vague. I can find no possible 
foundation for it unless he is again referring to the 
low temperature readings of the Mercury Thermometers. 
On his Hypothesis, and it seems the only 
possible one, I have to remark firstly that I have 
already thrown light on the extent of the so called 
difficulty and secondly, that to sell the instances of 
default Dr Shaw has had recourse to the double mention 
of a single instance. 
The position with regard to the second 
paragraph of the 'Miscarriage of Instructions' is 
<u>therefore<u>
